required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Propofol Versus Ketamine for Moderate Procedural Sedation in the Emergency Department (ED)
clinical_study.official_title: Propofol Versus Ketamine for Procedural Sedation During Painful Procedures in the Emergency Department

brief_summary.textblock: This study is a clinical trial of moderate sedation with propofol versus moderate sedation with ketamine for procedural sedation in the Emergency Department.

primary_outcome.time_frame: From one minute prior to start of the procedure until the patient has returned to baseline mental status after the conclusion of the sedation procedure up to 60 minutes)
primary_outcome.description: binary measure based on the occurrence of an oxygen saturation less than 93 at any time, a change in baseline end tidal co2 >10 or an absence on capnographic waveform

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Return of Baseline Mental Status
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from start of procedure until the return of baseline mental status up to 120 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: time in seconds from the first dose of medication until the patient has regained baseline mental status

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient Reported Pain or Recall of the Procedure
secondary_outcome.time_frame: single measurement immediately after patient returns to baseline mental status after sedation procedure
secondary_outcome.description: patient completed question after return to baseline mental status "did you feel pain during the procedure" and "do you remember any part of the procedure" answered by circling yes or no on a question sheet, positive if yes to either question
Observes assesment of alertness scale, 1-5 ordinal scale measuring level of awareness, one represents awake, 5 general anesthesia/unresponsive to pain

arm_group.description: propofol 1 milligram per kilogram intravenous bolus followed by 0.5 millligrams per kilogram as needed for mooderate procedural sedation
ketamine 1 milligram per kilogram followed by 0.5 millgram per kilogram as needed for moderate procedural sedation

intervention.description: propofol 1 millgram per kilogram intravenous bolus followed by 0.5 milligrams per kilogram as needed for moderate procedural sedation
ketamine milligram per kilogram followed by 0.5 milligrams per kilogram as need for moderate procedural sedation

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients who require moderate procedural sedation with propofol in the ED
Exclusion Criteria:
- age > 17 years
- pregnant
- intoxicated
- cannot give informed consent
- allergy to ketamine or propofol
- patient will require deep procedural sedation
- ASA physical status score > 2

results_reference.citation: Miner JR, Gray RO, Bahr J, Patel R, McGill JW. Randomized clinical trial of propofol versus ketamine for procedural sedation in the emergency department. Acad Emerg Med. 2010 Jun;17(6):604-11. doi: 10.1111/j.1553-2712.2010.00776.x.

clinical_study.keyword: moderate procedural sedation in the ED

participant_flow.recruitment_details: 100 patients recruited in the Emergency Department

group.title: Propofol
group.description: propofol 1 milligram per kilogram at the start of the procedure followed by 0.5 milligrams per kilogram every 3 minutes as needed for moderate procedural sedation

group.title: Ketamine
group.description: ketamine 1 milligram per kilogram intravenous bolus to start procedure followed by 0.5 mg/kg every three minutes as needed for moderate procedural sedation

drop_withdraw_reason.title: did not undergo sedation after enrollmen

group.title: Propofol
group.description: propofol 1 milligram per kilogram at the start of the procedure followed by 0.5 milligrams per kilogram every 3 minutes as needed for moderate procedural sedation

group.title: Ketamine
group.description: ketamine 1 milligram per kilogram intravenous bolus to start procedure followed by 0.5 mg/kg every three minutes as needed for moderate procedural sedation

outcome.title: Respiratory Depression (Sub-clinical and Clinical Signs)
outcome.description: binary measure based on the occurrence of an oxygen saturation less than 93 at any time, a change in baseline end tidal co2 >10 or an absence on capnographic waveform
outcome.time_frame: From one minute prior to start of the procedure until the patient has returned to baseline mental status after the conclusion of the sedation procedure up to 60 minutes)
outcome.population: 50 subjects were randomized to each group, 50 subjects in the propofol arm completed the study, 47 in the ketamine arm

group.title: Propofol
group.description: percentage of participants with respiratory depression

group.title: Ketamine
group.description: percentage of participants with respiratory depression

measure.title: Respiratory Depression (Sub-clinical and Clinical Signs)

measure.population: 50 subjects were randomized to each group, 50 subjects in the propofol arm completed the study, 47 in the ketamine arm

outcome.title: Time to Return of Baseline Mental Status
outcome.description: time in seconds from the first dose of medication until the patient has regained baseline mental status
outcome.time_frame: from start of procedure until the return of baseline mental status up to 120 minutes
outcome.population: 50 patients were randomized to the propofol group and 50 to ketamine, 50 underwent the procedure in the propofol group and 47 in the ketamine group

measure.description: patient completed question after return to baseline mental status "did you feel pain during the procedure" and "do you remember any part of the procedure" answered by circling yes or no on a question sheet, positive if yes to either question

outcome.title: Depth of Sedation
outcome.description: Observes assesment of alertness scale, 1-5 ordinal scale measuring level of awareness, one represents awake, 5 general anesthesia/unresponsive to pain
outcome.population: 100 patients were randomized, 50 to the propofol group, 50 of whom underwent sedation, and 50 in the ketamine group, 47 of whom underwent sedation

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
